div.p: Why decorate sugar cookies?

Decorating sugar cookies with royal icing is a challenge. However, the outcome is often beautiful (and delicious!). Custom, hand-decorated cookies are expensive, so learning to decorate on your own can be very rewarding!

Detailed decorating takes focus; it can be a way to slow down, relax, and direct your attention towards something besides life's normal stressors. The best part of sugar cookie decorating is that if you make a mistake, you can just eat it!

html.css:font-family: serif, Times, Times New Roman, Symbol, MingLiU, MS Mincho, Arial Unicode MS

div.p: Explanation of royal icing in relation to sugar cookies.
Royal icing is used to decorate sugar cookies because it dries quickly and its consistency is nice to work with when decorating.
Mastering icing consistency is the key to successful sugar cookie decorating.

Royal icing is finicky and hard to work with until you get to know it through lots of hands-on practice. Many people give up because it's tricky to master. You might need several tries to get it right.

Royal icing consistency is affected by the humidity in the air. Therefore, a specific ratio of water in any given recipe may have different results on different days when mixing for the consistency you desire.
Watch videos on YouTube to learn how to get the right icing consistencies.

div.p: Tools needed to make royal icing and decorate sugar cookies.

ul.li: One small bowl per icing color
One piping bag per icing color
Your piping bags filled with flooding and decorating icings

div.p: Ingredients needed to make royal icing.

html.css:font-family: serif, Times, Times New Roman, Symbol, MingLiU, MS Mincho, Arial Unicode MS

div.domains: (map mapgroup-d) (map bookmap) (topic abbrev-d) (topic delay-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (map ditavalref-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic xnal-d) (topic markup-d xml-d)

article.h1: | - Chapter . How to make white royal icing

div.p: How to make your base royal icing.

section.p: This is your basic royal icing. You will later modify the consistency of this icing to make flooding icing and detail piping icing.
Do NOT overmix your icing. Overmixed royal icing doesn't dry well on cookies and will easily crumble and fall off the cookie. It also tastes disgusting.

li.span: Whisk meringue powder and warm water together by hand with a small whisk in a large mixing bowl.
Whisk in light corn syrup, vanilla extract, and almond extract.
Add the powdered sugar to the bowl.
Move your bowl to a mixer and mix on low speed with a paddle for 30 seconds or until combined.
Scrape bottom and sides of bowl with a spatula.
Continue mixing on low speed for 2-3 minutes.
Look for stiff peaks in icing. To do this, put your paddle or a spoon into the icing and then pull it out. The icing peaks should stay formed with little to no bending or falling over.
If peaks are not stiff, mix for 1 more minute.
Cover in airtight container to prevent drying.

html.css:font-family: serif, Times, Times New Roman, Symbol, MingLiU, MS Mincho, Arial Unicode MS

div.domains: (map mapgroup-d) (map bookmap) (topic abbrev-d) (topic delay-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (map ditavalref-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic xnal-d) (topic markup-d xml-d)

article.h1: | - Chapter . How to color and thin your icing

div.p: How to color and thin royal icing.

section.p: Royal icing is colored by mixing small amounts of water and food gel coloring into the icing bowl. At times, a few drops of water makes the difference between too thick, too thin, or just right.
Each icing color should be mixed in a separate bowl.

li.span: Squeeze a drop or two of gel food coloring into your bowl of icing.
Thin your icing to the right consistency by adding small amounts of water with a half-teaspoon or a small spray bottle.
Cover in airtight container or place in piping bag or close.

article.h2: Note on deep and dark icing colors

div.p: Deep or dark colors such as red, navy blue, and black require a great deal of food coloring.

Colors intensify across time. If a dark color is needed, mix a good amount of color into the icing, then let icing sit in airtight bowl for at least two hours. This allows the color to darken and prevents you from adding too much coloring.
Dark colors tend to stain the mouth when eaten.

html.css:font-family: serif, Times, Times New Roman, Symbol, MingLiU, MS Mincho, Arial Unicode MS

article.h1: | - Chapter . How to fill a piping bag

div.p: How to fill a piping bag.
div.section: Once you're ready to start decorating, fill your piping bags with icing.

li.span: Open bag and place inside a tall glass, then cuff bag over sides so it holds itself open.
Pour or scrape your icing into the bag.
Close bag by tying a knot, using a bag clip, or using a twistie.

html.css:font-family: serif, Times, Times New Roman, Symbol, MingLiU, MS Mincho, Arial Unicode MS

div.p: An explanation of the flooding technique.
Flooding gives your cookie an even base layer of icing to which you can later add details.
Icing used for flooding should have a consistency that is thin enough to flow into itself but thick enough that it doesn't drip off the cookie.
A perfectly flooded cookie has even thickness across the cookies, is a little puffy, and has a slight shine after it has dried.
You can flood cookies in sections to add dimension, or flood the entire cookie at once.

html.css:font-family: serif, Times, Times New Roman, Symbol, MingLiU, MS Mincho, Arial Unicode MS

div.domains: (map mapgroup-d) (map bookmap) (topic abbrev-d) (topic delay-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (map ditavalref-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic xnal-d) (topic markup-d xml-d)

article.h1: | - Chapter . How to flood a cookie

div.p: How to flood a cookie in the current style.

section.p: The directions below explain how to flood in the current preferred style.

li.span: Outline the portion of the cookie you want to flood.
Immediately fill inside of the outline with icing.
Gently pull icing out to edges using a scribe tool.
Pop air bubbles and close frosting gaps with scribe tool.
If needed, level your icing by gently shaking cookie side-to-side.

html.css:font-family: serif, Times, Times New Roman, Symbol, MingLiU, MS Mincho, Arial Unicode MS

div.domains: (map mapgroup-d) (map bookmap) (topic abbrev-d) (topic delay-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (map ditavalref-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic xnal-d) (topic markup-d xml-d)

article.h1: | - Chapter . How to do the wet-on-wet icing technique

div.p: How to do the wet-on-wet icing technique.
div.section: The wet-on-wet icing technique allows you to add details with other colors while the flood layer is still wet and hasn't crusted. Your base flood icing and colored icing details will dry as one even layer.

li.span: Flood cookie with base color.
Immediately add details with colored icing of same consistency.

article.h2: How to create polka dots with wet-on-wet icing technique

div.p: How to create polka dots with the wet-on-wet icing technique.
div.section: Polka dots are an easy way to use the wet-on-wet icing technique.

li.span: Squeeze piping bag gently to drop spots of colored icing into flooded base icing.
Release pressure on piping bag while lifting away from cookie.
Let crust and dry.

article.h2: How to create stripes with wet-on-wet icing technique

div.p: How to create stripes with wet-on-wet icing technique.
div.section: You can make stripes using the wet-on-wet icing technique.

li.span: Touch colored icing piping bag down on edge of flooded base icing.
Lift icing bag slightly. Icing should hang from bag.
Apply gentle, even pressure and pull icing across cookie in a straight line.
Touch tip of piping bag down on end of line, then release pressure.
Let crust and dry.

article.h2: How to create zig-zags with wet-on-wet icing technique

div.p: How to create zig-zags with wet-on-wet icing technique.

section.p: Zig-zags are a more advanced wet-on-wet icing technique.

li.span: Pipe stripes, but do not let crust and dry.
Gently drag scribe tool perpendicular to direction of stripes.
Let crust and dry.

html.css:font-family: serif, Times, Times New Roman, Symbol, MingLiU, MS Mincho, Arial Unicode MS

div.domains: (map mapgroup-d) (map bookmap) (topic abbrev-d) (topic delay-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (map ditavalref-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic xnal-d) (topic markup-d xml-d)

div.p: Detail piping is often the key to gorgeous sugar cookies.
Once your base layer has crusted, you can add details. Common details include fine lines, flowers, script, and eyes.
Icing for detail piping must be thicker than flood icing, about the consistency of toothpaste.
Wait for each detail icing layer to dry before adding another for the most successful detail piping.
Extensive details can take hours and may be done over 1-3 days. Small details make beautiful cookies!
